results.title: The Many faces of epilepsy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Speaking from experience”.
Epilepsy affects 3% of the Australian population and manifests itself in many different ways to individuals, families and communities. Epilepsy sufferers and their families discuss the symptoms they experience (varying from stumbling, absent seizures, tonic clonic), the success/failure and side effects of medication, reaction to diagnosis, what it feels like to have a seizure (daydreaming, contortion, deja vu), how the symptoms change with age, warning signs, the impact on employment and relationships, disclosure and impact on lifestyle.

results.title: Epilepsy in childhood
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Speaking from experience”.
Parents and children discuss the circumstances and behaviour that led to their child being diagnosed with epilepsy, ranging from seizures to staring into space. They explain their very personal initial reaction to the news, deciding whether to medicate or not, the importance of a good relationship with medical staff, the impact on family and friends, schooling, lifestyle changes, and how their children have changed with age and on receiving medication.

results.title: Living with breast cancer
results.creator_credit: Anti Cancer Council, Giovanna Pignaiosa, Gillian Fawcett, Cancer Council Victoria and Speaking From Experience
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Speaking from experience”.
Breast cancer is a malignant tumor in the breast. The severity of the disease depends on the size of the cancer and whether it has spread to other parts of the body. This excellent and informative documentary presents five women of varying age, who have all experienced the trauma of breast cancer. Each woman relates her own personal story from the initial diagnosis and having to deal with the reality, to surgery and treatment and finally to recovery and the future. Various types of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy are discussed including the side effects, physical and emotional, and the important role self-image can play in the road to recovery. Also stresses that the key to recovery is through support from family and friends in terms of encouragement, offers of help in daily routines, and generally in just being there. A common factor with each of the women is the way their outlook on life has changed, valuing each day as precious and maintaining a positive attitude as a means to coping with the disease. A warm and enlightening progam.

results.title: Grief, trauma and sexual abuse: the stories of two women
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Speaking from experience”.
Aimed at increasing awareness and consciousness of the crimes depicted, this episode from the “Speaking from experience” series looks at the experiences of Lucy and Tina. Lucy was sexually abused by her father as a young child; a situation that the remainder of her family was aware of. Tina was raped by an unknown assailant in her own home, a country property out of Melbourne. Both women speak candidly and honestly to varying degrees of detail about what happened to them, how they coped immediately afterwards and now, the impact it had on the rest of their family as well as intimate relationships, the benefits of talk therapy, the need for justice, and what has to be achieved to assist the healing process.

results.title: Alzheimer's disease and other dementias: Diagnosis = Speaking from experience
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Speaking from experience”.
This Australian program presents a sensitive account of Alzheimer’s disease from the point of view of their families and carers. It looks at the early signs and behaviours, and the ways in which the patients and their carers handle diagnosis of the condition. The emotional impact this disease has on families is openly discussed, as well as practical advice given on how carers can best handle the progression of the condition.
